September 15, 2013: Fiction
HOW THE LIGHT GETS IN, by Louise Penny. (Minotaur.) Chief Inspector Armand
Gamache of the Sûreté du Québec seeks a refuge in the tiny mountain village of
Three Pines.
THE CUCKOO'S CALLING, by Robert Galbraith. (Mullholland Books/Little,
Brown.) A struggling detective, Cormoran Strike, investigates s a supermodel’s
suicide; by J.K. Rowling, writing pseudonymously.
INFERNO, by Dan Brown. (Doubleday.) The symbologist Robert Langdon, on the
run in Florence, must decipher a series of codes created by a Dante-loving
scientist.
MISTRESS, by James Patterson and David Ellis. (Little, Brown.) When he begins
to investigate a friend’s mysterious death, a man discovers that she was leading a
double life.
AND THE MOUNTAINS ECHOED, by Khaled Hosseini. (Riverhead.) A
multigenerational family saga centers on a brother and sister born in Afghanistan.
THE WHOLE ENCHILADA, by Diane Mott Davidson. (Morrow/HarperCollins.)
Someone is stalking the caterer and sleuth Goldy Schulz.
BONES OF THE LOST, by Kathy Reichs. (Scribner.) The investigation of a hit-
and-run leads the forensic anthropologist Temperance Brennan into the world of
human trafficking; the 16th novel in the series behind the show “Bones.”
GONE GIRL, by Gillian Flynn. (Crown.) A woman disappears on her fifth
anniversary; is her husband a killer?
NIGHT FILM, by Marisha Pessl. (Random House.) Investigators pursue a master
horror film auteur after his daughter is found dead.
THE BONE SEASON, by Samantha Shannon. (Bloomsbury.) A young clairvoyant
discovers her powers in a dystopian England in 2059; the first pick of the “Today”
show book club.
THE HUSBAND'S SECRET, by Liane Moriarty. (Amy Einhorn/Putnam.) A
woman’s life is upended when she discovers a letter she was not meant to read.
KENOBI, by John Jackson Miller. (Del Rey.) The enigmatic stranger on the desert
planet of Tatooine is the Jedi master Obi-Wan Kenobi; a “Star Wars” novel.
THE KILL LIST, by Frederick Forsyth. (Putnam.) An Arabic-speaking Marine major
known as the Tracker pursues a terrorist who radicalizes young Muslims living
abroad.

Non-Fiction
THE LIBERTY AMENDMENTS, by Mark R. Levin. (Threshold Editions.) The talk-
radio host offers 11 proposals for returning to America's founding principles.
ZEALOT, by Reza Aslan. (Random House.) A biography of Jesus of Nazareth
presents him in the context of his times as the leader of a revolutionary movement.
THIS TOWN, by Mark Leibovich. (Blue Rider.) An examination of Washington’s
“media-industrial complex” by the chief national correspondent for The Times
Magazine.
LEAN IN, by Sheryl Sandberg with Nell Scovell. (Knopf.) The chief operating
officer of Facebook urges women to pursue their careers without ambivalence.
HAPPY, HAPPY, HAPPY, by Phil Robertson with Mark Schlabach. (Howard
Books.) The Duck Commander pays tribute to “faith, family and ducks.”
LAWRENCE IN ARABIA, by Scott Anderson. (Doubleday.) A history of the Arab
revolt against the Turks in World War I focuses on T.E. Lawrence and other
adventurers.
EXPOSED, by Jane Velez-Mitchell. (Morrow/HarperCollins.) The story of Jodi
Arias, who was convicted of murdering her boyfriend, Travis Alexander.
THE BUTLER, by Wil Haygood. (37 Ink/Atria.) The story of Eugene Allen, a butler
who served presidents from Harry Truman to Ronald Reagan. Haygood's article
about Allen inspired the movie "Lee Daniels' The Butler."
UNBROKEN, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Random House.) An Olympic runner’s story
of survival as a prisoner of the Japanese in World War II.
THE DUCK COMMANDER FAMILY, by Willie and Korie Robertson with Mark
Schlabach. (Howard Books.) Behind the scenes at the A&E show “Duck Dynasty.”
THE REASON I JUMP, by Naoki Higashida. (Random House.) A 13-year-old boy
with autism answers questions.
MANSON, by Jeff Guinn. (Simon & Schuster.) Charles Manson’s rise and fall,
seen in the context of the 1960s music industry.
THE SPORTS GENE, by David Epstein. (Current.) A study of the science of elite
athletic performance addresses questions about whether athletic skill is innate.
LET'S EXPLORE DIABETES WITH OWLS, by David Sedaris. (Little, Brown.)
Essays from the humorist on subjects like French dentistry and a North Carolina
Costco.
